intro: Amianthium texanum, commonly known as the Texas grass or Texas panicum, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States. It is a member of the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its tufted growth habit and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, pale blue to white flowers arranged in spikelets, which are typical of the grass family. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soils, often found in open fields and along roadsides. Amianthium texanum is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a hardy species in the southern regions of the U.S.
